defs.docs:
# Introduction
 Clarity is a low-level Ethereum transaction library written in pure Rust.

attributes.value: / Clarity is a low-level Ethereum transaction library written in pure Rust.
/ * ABI enconding for common data types (see `abi::Token` variants)
/ Here's an example lifetime of an Alice-to-Bob Ethereum transaction made with Clarity:
/ // A helper for filling the keys
/ // You can always derive the sender from a signed transaction
/ // Send the locally assembled raw transaction over web3 (no need to trust another
/ // machine with your wallet or host a node locally).

defs.name: abi
defs.docs: A module to simplify ABI encoding

attributes.value: / A module to simplify ABI encoding
/ For simplicity, it is based on tokens (as in items, not as in coin tokens). You have to specify a list of
/ tokens and they will be automatically encoded.
/ Additionally there are helpers to help deal with deriving a function
/ This is not a full fledged implementation of ABI encoder, it is more
/ like a bunch of helpers that would help to successfully encode a contract
/ Currently this module can only serialize types that can be represented by a [Token](#struct.Token).
/ Unfortunately if you need to support custom type that is not currently supported you are welcome to open an issue [on issues page](https://github.com/althea-net/clarity/issues/new),
/ or do the serialization yourself by converting your custom type into a `[u8; 32]` array and creating a proper Token instance.

defs.name: Token
defs.value:
pub enum Token {
    Uint(Uint256),
    Address(Address),
    Bool(bool),
    String(String),
    FixedString(String),
    Bytes(Vec<u8>),
    UnboundedBytes(Vec<u8>),
    Dynamic(Vec<Token>),
    Struct(Vec<Token>),
}
defs.docs: A token represents a value of parameter of the contract call.

attributes.value: / A token represents a value of parameter of the contract call.
/ For each supported type there is separate entry that later is helpful to determine

defs.name: SerializedToken
defs.docs: Representation of a serialized token.

attributes.value: / Serialization occurs once a list of tokens is passed. After that
/ the library will determine the actual ABI encoding of a each type wrapped in
/ a token, and then it will return a
/ With a list of values of type `SerializedToken` a caller can construct a final
/ binary data that will represent a valid ABI encoding of function parameters.

attributes.value: / Raw derive for a Keccak256 digest from a string
/ This function should be used when trying to filter out interesting
/ events from a contract. This is different than contract function
/ calls because it uses whole 32 bytes of the hash digest.

defs.name: get_hash
defs.docs:
Gets the Keccak256 hash of some input bytes. Signatures in Ethereum are nearly without
 exception performed after encoding using the ABI, then hashing using this function.

defs.name: Error
defs.value:
pub enum Error {
    InvalidNetworkId,
    InvalidV,
    InvalidR,
    InvalidS,
    InvalidSignatureValues,
    ZeroPrivKey,
    InvalidPrivKeyLength {
        got: usize,
        expected: usize,
    },
    DecodePrivKey(secp256k1::Error),
    DecodeRecoveryId(secp256k1::Error),
    ParseMessage(secp256k1::Error),
    ParseRecoverableSignature(secp256k1::Error),
    RecoverSignature(secp256k1::Error),
    InvalidAddressLength {
        got: usize,
        expected: usize,
    },
    InvalidUtf8(Utf8Error),
    InvalidHex(ParseIntError),
    InvalidEip55,
    InvalidCallError(String),
    InvalidSignatureLength,
    SerializeRlp,
    DeserializeRlp,
    NoSignature,
}
defs.docs:

defs.name: sign_hash
defs.docs: Signs a message that is represented by a hash contained in a binary form.

attributes.value: / Signs a message that is represented by a hash contained in a binary form.
/ Requires the data buffer to be exactly 32 bytes in length. You can prepare
/ an input using a hashing function such as `Keccak256` which will return
/ You are advised, though, to use [sign_msg](#method.sign_msg)
/ which is more user friendly version that uses Keccak256 internally.

defs.name: sign_msg
defs.docs: Signs any message represented by a slice of data.

attributes.value: / Signs any message represented by a slice of data.
/ Internally it makes `Keccak256` hash out of your data, and then creates a
/ This is more user friendly version of [sign_hash](#method.sign_hash) which means
/ it will use `Keccak256` function to hash your input data.
/ This method is deprecated as insecure, since it does not prevent signed messages
/ from being possibly valid transactions by appending the standard \x19Ethereum Signed Message:\n32

deprecated(since = "0.3.2", note =
             "Please use sign_ethereum_msg or sign_insecure_msg instead")

defs.name: sign_insecure_msg
defs.docs: Signs any message represented by a slice of data.

attributes.value: / Signs any message represented by a slice of data.
/ Internally it makes `Keccak256` hash out of your data, and then creates a
/ This is more user friendly version of [sign_hash](#method.sign_hash) which means
/ it will use `Keccak256` function to hash your input data.
/ This method is provided on the assumption you know what you are doing, it does not prevent signed messages
/ from being possibly valid transactions. No Ethereum signed message salt is appended. Use with Caution!

defs.name: sign_ethereum_msg
defs.docs: Signs any message represented by a slice of data.

attributes.value: / Signs any message represented by a slice of data.
/ Internally it makes `Keccak256` hash out of your data, and then creates a
/ This is more user friendly version of [sign_hash](#method.sign_hash) which means
/ it will use `Keccak256` function to hash your input data.
/ Remember this function appends \x19Ethereum Signed Message:\n32 to your hash! so
/ you may need to take that into account when you go to verify

defs.name: into_bytes
defs.docs: Converts a signature into a bytes string.

attributes.value: / Converts a signature into a bytes string.
/ A signature in binary form consists of 65 bytes where
/ first 32 bytes are "r" in big endian form, next 32 bytes are "s"
/ in big endian form, and at the end there is one byte made of "v".

 you may need to insert that yourself after matching on errors

/ This is done this way to overcome the "orphan rule" where you can't
/ implement traits for a type that comes from different crate.

defs.name: get_ethereum_msg_hash
defs.docs:
Takes a signature payload of arbitrary size and creates a proper payload
 for an ethereum_msg signature.

attributes.value: / Takes a signature payload of arbitrary size and creates a proper payload
/ Internally this means `Keccak256` hashing the data, appending the Ethereum signed
/ msg constant, then hashing it again.
/ This is how you would verify the data from [sign_ethereum_msg](#method.sign_ethereum_msg)
/ // on the other side verifying the signature
